importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the US-proposed ceasefire deal was signed, marking a key turning point in the conflict and triggering the agreement for the return of deceased hostages.
The date when the two coffins containing deceased hostages were transferred into Israel, indicating ongoing progress (or challenges) in fulfilling the ceasefire agreement.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The original terms of the ceasefire agreement stipulated that Hamas should return all deceased hostages within 72 hours of the deal going into effect, raising concerns about compliance and logistical challenges.

keyTakeAways: The Israeli military confirmed that two coffins, believed to contain the remains of deceased hostages, were transferred into Israel from Gaza by Hamas under the terms of the US-proposed ceasefire agreement.
The bodies are currently being identified at the National Institute for Forensic Medicine, with the Israeli Ministry of Health confirming their arrival.
These would be the 14th and 15th deceased hostages to be transferred since the ceasefire was signed on October 9, 2025.
Hamas has returned 13 of the 28 deceased hostages previously agreed to be released, with all of those 13 now formally identified.
One previously delivered body was not confirmed to belong to an Israeli hostage, suggesting possible misidentification by Hamas, though Israeli sources believe it was not intentional.
Hamas has stated that significant efforts and special equipment are needed to recover bodies buried under rubble, indicating serious logistical challenges.
The transfer of the new two coffins occurred shortly after US Vice President JD Vance arrived in Israel, signaling continued US involvement in the ceasefire implementation.
Vance emphasized that while recovery is difficult and not going to happen overnight, it is a priority for families to recover the bodies for proper burial.
Israeli officials stress sensitivity and caution against speculation, urging the public to wait for official identification before sharing information with families.

namedEntities.name: Israel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nation involved in the conflict; the military and government are directly engaged in the operation of returning hostages and enforcing the ceasefire agreement.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Israel is central to the article as it is the state that received the coffins, is responsible for identifying the bodies, and is enforcing the terms of the ceasefire deal with Hamas.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A militant group that controls parts of Gaza and is directly involved in the conflict; it is required under the ceasefire to return the deceased hostages.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is the entity responsible for transferring the coffins into Israel under the ceasefire agreement, and the article highlights disputes over compliance, accuracy, and logistics in the process.

namedEntities.name: Al-Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The armed wing of Hamas responsible for military actions and operations in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Al-Qassam Brigades is cited as the group that announced the scheduled transfer of the two coffins, indicating its direct role in the body-handing process and ceasefire implementation.

namedEntities.name: Israel Defense Forces (IDF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The military forces of Israel responsible for security, border control, and operations in the conflict.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The IDF is directly involved in receiving, escorting, and processing the coffins into Israel, and is responsible for ensuring the safety and proper handling of the remains.

namedEntities.name: Israel Security Agency (ISA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli intelligence agency involved in security and monitoring operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ISA jointly issued a statement with the IDF confirming the transfer, indicating its role in intelligence and coordination of the ceasefire-related operations.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A foreign power that proposed and facilitated the ceasefire deal.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US proposed the ceasefire agreement, and its representative, Vice President JD Vance, is present in Israel, signaling international involvement and diplomatic pressure on both sides.

namedEntities.name: JD Vance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: US Vice President who visited Israel and commented on the ceasefire and hostage recovery efforts.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vance’s public statements underscore the US role in supporting the ceasefire and emphasize the moral urgency of recovering the hostages, even amid logistical difficulties.

namedEntities.name: National Institute for Forensic Medicine
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli institution responsible for forensic identification and analysis of human remains.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This institution is where the bodies are being identified and investigated, making it a critical node in the verification and accountability process.

namedEntities.name: Sergeant Major Tal Haimi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli soldier whose body was identified among the 13 returned bodies under the ceasefire agreement.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His identification marks a key milestone in the process of confirming the identities of deceased hostages, showing progress in the recovery efforts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Israeli military confirmed that two coffins containing the remains of deceased hostages were transferred from Gaza into Israel under the terms of the US-proposed ceasefire agreement signed on October 9, 2025. These would be the 14th and 15th such bodies returned since the deal was initiated. The coffins were handed over by Hamas, which has previously returned 13 bodies, all of which have been formally identified. One of the earlier bodies was misidentified, suggesting possible errors in recovery or reporting. The bodies are now being processed at Israel’s National Institute for Forensic Medicine for identification and cause-of-death investigation. The Israeli government has urged the public to remain sensitive and wait for official confirmation before sharing information with families. US Vice President JD Vance emphasized the difficulty of recovering bodies buried under rubble and stated that while the process is complex, it is a moral imperative. The situation reflects broader challenges in fulfilling the ceasefire agreement, particularly due to Hamas’s stated difficulties in locating and retrieving bodies, and the potential for misidentification.
title: Israeli Military Says Two Coffins Said to Contain Hostages’ Bodies Cross Into Israel
